description:
Dactylosporangium cerinum is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Dactylosporangium. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and spore-forming bacterium. The cells of D. cerinum are typically rod-shaped and can form branched, mycelium-like structures. The species is known to produce characteristic sporangia (spore-bearing structures) that are arranged in a finger-like or dactyloid pattern, which is the origin of the genus name Dactylosporangium.

D. cerinum was first isolated from soil samples and is found in various terrestrial environments. It is known to be capable of degrading complex organic compounds and can contribute to the cycling of nutrients in the soil ecosystem. The species is considered an actinobacterium, a group of bacteria known for their ability to produce a wide range of secondary metabolites, some of which may have potential applications in medicine or biotechnology.
